generalfeedback.text:
In order to solve this problem we will have to use the linearity rules for differentition. <hint>calc_diff_linearity_rule</hint>
\[\begin{array}{rcl}\displaystyle \frac{d}{d@v@}\left[ @p@\right] &\displaystyle =&\displaystyle \frac{d}{d@v@}\left[@pp1@\right] +\frac{d}{d@v@}\left(@pp2@\right) \\ &\displaystyle =&\displaystyle @rdm1@\cdot \frac{d}{d@v@}[@ppp1@]+\frac{d}{d@v@}\left(@ppp2@\right) \\ &\displaystyle =&\displaystyle @rdm1@\cdot [@diff(ppp1,v)@]+@diff(ppp2,v)@ \\ &\displaystyle =&\displaystyle @diff(p,v)@ \end{array}\]

truefeedback.text:
You appear to have forgotten the coefficients @rdm1@ and @rdm2@.
Remember: \[\frac{d}{dx}(k\cdot f)=k\cdot \frac{df}{dx}.\]

\[\begin{array}{rcl}\displaystyle \frac{d}{d@v@}\left[ @p@\right] &\displaystyle =&\displaystyle \frac{d}{d@v@}\left[@pp1@\right] +\frac{d}{d@v@}\left[@pp2@\right]+\frac{d}{d@v@}\left[@pp3@\right] \\ &\displaystyle =&\displaystyle \frac{d}{d@v@}[@ppp1@]+\frac{d}{d@v@}\left[@ppp2@\right] +@rdm3@\cdot \frac{d}{d@v@}\left[@ppp3@\right] \\ &\displaystyle =&\displaystyle @diff(ppp1,v)@+[@diff(ppp2,v)@]+@rdm3@\cdot \left[@diff(ppp3,v)@\right] \\ &\displaystyle =&\displaystyle @diff(p,v)@ \end{array}\]

\[\begin{array}{rcl}\displaystyle \frac{d}{d@v@}\left[ @p@\right] &\displaystyle =&\displaystyle \frac{d}{d@v@}\left[@pp1@\right] +\frac{d}{d@v@}\left[@pp2@\right]+\frac{d}{d@v@}\left[@pp3@\right] \\ &\displaystyle =&\displaystyle @rdm1@\cdot \frac{d}{d@v@}[@ppp1@]+@rdm2@\cdot \frac{d}{d@v@}\left[@ppp2@\right] +@rdm3@\cdot \frac{d}{d@v@}\left[@ppp3@\right] \\ &\displaystyle =&\displaystyle @rdm1@\cdot [@diff(ppp1,v)@]+@rdm2@\cdot [@diff(ppp2,v)@] +@rdm3@\cdot \left[@diff(ppp3,v)@\right] \\ &\displaystyle =&\displaystyle @diff(p,v)@ \end{array}\]

In order to solve this problem we will have to use the linearity rules for differentition. <hint>calc_diff_linearity_rule</hint>
\[\begin{array}{rcl}\displaystyle \frac{d}{d@v@}\left( @p@\right) &\displaystyle =&\displaystyle \frac{d}{d@v@}\left( @pp1@\right) +\frac{d}{d@v@}\left[ @pp2@\right] \\ &\displaystyle =&\displaystyle @rdm1@\cdot \frac{d}{d@v@}(@ppp1@)+@1/rdm2@\cdot \frac{d}{d@v@}[@ppp2@] \\ &\displaystyle =&\displaystyle @rdm1@\cdot \left( @diff(ppp1,v)@\right) +@1/rdm2@\cdot \left[ @diff(ppp2,v)@\right] \\ &\displaystyle =&\displaystyle @rdm1*diff(ppp1,v)@+@1/rdm2*diff(ppp2,v)@ \end{array}\]

questiontext.text:
Expand the powers and find the following derivative: \[ \frac{d}{d@v@}\left[\sqrt{@pp@}\right] . \]
[[input:ans1]] [[validation:ans1]]

generalfeedback.text:
In order to solve this problem we will have to use the linearity rules for differentition <hint>calc_diff_linearity_rule</hint> and the properties of exponentials <hint>alg_indices</hint>.
\[\begin{array}{rcl}\displaystyle \frac{d}{d@v@}\left[\sqrt{\left(@pp@\right)}\right] &\displaystyle =&\displaystyle \frac{d}{d@v@}\left( @p@\right) \\ &\displaystyle =&\displaystyle @rdm1^(1/2)@\cdot \frac{d}{d@v@}(@ppp^(1/2)@) \\ &\displaystyle =&\displaystyle @rdm1^(1/2)@\cdot @diff(ppp^(1/2),v)@ \\ &\displaystyle =&\displaystyle @diff(p,v)@ \end{array}\]

truefeedback.text:
The derivative of $af(x) = a\frac{df}{dx}$
You appear to have dropped the a factor, in this case @rdm1^(1/2)@

questiontext.text:
Expand the powers and find the following derivative: \[ \frac{d}{d@v@}\left[\left(@pp@\right)^{@rdm2@}\right] . \]
[[input:ans1]] [[validation:ans1]]

generalfeedback.text:
In order to solve this problem we will have to use the linearity rules for differentition. <hint>calc_diff_linearity_rule</hint>
\[\begin{array}{rcl}\displaystyle \frac{d}{d@v@}\left[\left(@pp@\right)^{@rdm2@}\right] &\displaystyle =&\displaystyle \frac{d}{d@v@}\left( @p@\right) \\ &\displaystyle =&\displaystyle @rdm1^rdm2@\cdot \frac{d}{d@v@}(@ppp^rdm2@) \\ &\displaystyle =&\displaystyle @rdm1^rdm2@\cdot @diff(ppp^rdm2,v)@ \\ &\displaystyle =&\displaystyle @rdm1^rdm2*diff(ppp^rdm2,v)@ \end{array}\]

truefeedback.text:
The derivative of $ae^x = ae^x$
You appear to have dropped the a factor, in this case @rdm1**rdm2@

The derivative of $e^{mx} = me^{mx}$.
You appear to have lost the m factor in the exponent.

The derivative of $e^{mx} = me^x$.
You appear to have lost the m factor.

questiontext.text:
Expand the following expresion and differentiate it with respect to @v@:\[ @p@. \]
[[input:ans1]] [[validation:ans1]]

generalfeedback.text:
In order to solve this problem we will have to use the linearity rules for differentition. <hint>calc_diff_linearity_rule</hint>
Since
\[@p@=@q@,\]
\[\begin{array}{rcl}\displaystyle \frac{d}{d@v@}\left[ @p@\right] &\displaystyle =&\displaystyle \frac{d}{d@v@}\left( @q@\right) \\ &\displaystyle =&\displaystyle \frac{d}{d@v@}\left( @qq1@\right) + \frac{d}{d@v@}\left( @qq2@\right) + \frac{d}{d@v@}\left( @qq3@\right) + \frac{d}{d@v@}\left( @qq4@\right) \\ &\displaystyle =&\displaystyle @rdm1*rdm3@\frac{d}{d@v@}\left( @qqq1@\right) + @rdm1@\frac{d}{d@v@}\left( @qqq2@\right) + [@rdm2*rdm3@]\frac{d}{d@v@}\left( @qqq3@\right) + 0 \\ &\displaystyle =&\displaystyle @rdm1*rdm3@\left[@diff(qqq1,v)@\right] + (@rdm1@)@diff(qqq2,v)@ + [@rdm2*rdm3@]\left[@diff(qqq3,v)@\right] \\ &\displaystyle =&\displaystyle @rdm1*rdm3*diff(qqq1,v)@ + @rdm1*diff(qqq2,v)@ + @rdm2*rdm3*diff(qqq3,v)@ \end{array}\]

truefeedback.text: You seem to have used the sum rule to differentiate a product. Use to product rule instead <hint>calc_product_rule</hint>.

The derivative of a product is not the product of the derivative of each factor seperately.
To differentiate a product you need to use the product rule <hint>calc_product_rule</hint>.

questiontext.text:
Expand the following expresion and differentiate it with respect to @v@:\[ \frac{@pp1@}{@pp2@}. \]
[[input:ans1]] [[validation:ans1]]

generalfeedback.text:
In order to solve this problem we will have to use the linearity rules for differentition. <hint>calc_diff_linearity_rule</hint>
Since \[\begin{array}{rcl}\displaystyle \frac{@pp1@}{@pp2@} &\displaystyle =&\displaystyle \frac{1}{@pp2@}-\frac{@ppp2@}{@pp2@} \\ &\displaystyle =&\displaystyle @q@ \end{array}\]
\[\begin{array}{rcl}\displaystyle \frac{d}{d@v@}\left[\frac{@pp1@}{@pp2@}\right] &\displaystyle =&\displaystyle \frac{d}{d@v@}\left( @q@\right) \\ &\displaystyle =&\displaystyle \frac{d}{d@v@}\left(@1/pp2@\right) - \frac{d}{d@v@}\left( @ppp2/pp2@\right) \\ &\displaystyle =&\displaystyle @diff(q,v)@ \end{array}\]

questiontext.text: Use the laws of logarithms to find the following derivative: \[ \frac{d}{d@v@} \left[\ln(@pp@)\right]. \] [[input:ans1]] [[validation:ans1]]

generalfeedback.text: Using the laws of logarithms alg_logarithms we get \[\begin{array}{rcl}\displaystyle \ln(@pp@) &\displaystyle =&\displaystyle @rdm1@@pq@ \end{array}\] So, by linearity calc_diff_linearity_rule, \[\begin{array}{rcl}\displaystyle \frac{d}{d@v@}\left[\ln(@pp@)\right] &\displaystyle =&\displaystyle \frac{d}{d@v@}\left[@rdm1@@pq@\right] \\ &\displaystyle =&\displaystyle @rdm1@\frac{d}{dx}[@pq@] \\ &\displaystyle =&\displaystyle @rdm1@@diff(pq,v)@ \\ &\displaystyle =&\displaystyle @diff(p,v)@ \end{array}\]

questiontext.text: Use the laws of logarithms to find the following derivative: \[ \frac{d}{d@v@} \left[@p@\right]. \] [[input:ans1]] [[validation:ans1]]

generalfeedback.text: Using the laws of logarithms alg_logarithms we get \[\begin{array}{rcl}\displaystyle @p@ &\displaystyle =&\displaystyle \ln(1) - \ln(@pp@) \\ &\displaystyle =&\displaystyle -\ln(@ppp@) - \ln(@rdm2@) \\ &\displaystyle =&\displaystyle @-rdm1@@pq@ - \ln(@rdm2@) \end{array}\] So, by linearity calc_diff_linearity_rule, \[\begin{array}{rcl}\displaystyle \frac{d}{d@v@}\left[@p@\right] &\displaystyle =&\displaystyle \frac{d}{d@v@}\left[@-rdm1@@pq@ - \ln(@rdm2@)\right] \\ &\displaystyle =&\displaystyle \frac{d}{d@v@}\left[@-rdm1@@pq@\right] + \frac{d}{d@v@}\left[-\ln(@rdm2@)\right] \\ &\displaystyle =&\displaystyle @-rdm1@\frac{d}{d@v@}\left[@pq@\right] + 0 \\ &\displaystyle =&\displaystyle @-rdm1@@diff(pq,v)@ \\ &\displaystyle =&\displaystyle @-rdm1*diff(pq,v)@ \end{array}\]
